sen.j: 津田仙（つだ せん、天保8年7月6日 (旧暦)（1837年8月6日） - 1908年4月24日）は、日本の農学者、キリスト者。
sen.e: Sen TSUDA (August 6, 1837 - April 24, 1908) was a Japanese agriculturist and a Christian.
Sen TSUDA (August 6, 1837 - April 24, 1908) was a Japanese agriculturist and a Christian.
Sen TSUDA (August 6, 1837 - April 24, 1908) was a Japanese agriculturist and a Christian.

sen.j: 同志社大学・青山学院大学・筑波大学附属盲学校の創立に関わる。
sen.e: He was involved in founding Doshisha University, Aoyama Gakuin University, and the School for the Visually Impaired, University of Tsukuba.
He was involved in the founding of Doshisha University, Aoyama Gakuin University, and the School for the Visually Impaired in University of Tsukuba.
sen.cmt: 自然な表現になるよう修正しました。
sen.e: He was involved in the founding of Doshisha University, Aoyama Gakuin University, and the School for the Visually Impaired in University of Tsukuba.

sen.j: また、日本で最初に通信販売を行った人物でもある。
sen.e: He was also the first person to introduce a mail order service in Japan.
He was also the first person to start a mail order business in Japan.
sen.cmt: 自然な表現になるよう修正しました。
sen.e: He was also the first person to start a mail order business in Japan.

sen.j: 同志社大の創始者新島襄、人間の自由と平等を説いた東京大学教授の中村正直とともに、"キリスト教界の三傑"とうたわれた。
sen.e: Along with Joseph Hardy NEESIMA (Joe NIIJIMA), a founder of the Doshisha, and Masanao NAKAMURA, a professor of the University of Tokyo who preached human freedom and equality, he was known as one of "the three outstanding people of the Christianity world."

Along with Joseph Hardy NEESIMA (Joe NIIJIMA), one of the founders of the Doshisha, and Masanao NAKAMURA, a liberalist professor of the University of Tokyo, he was known as one of the three pillars of the Christian world.
sen.cmt: キリスト教界の三傑→three pillars of Christianity人間の自由と平等を説う→liberalism
sen.e: Along with Joseph Hardy NEESIMA (Joe NIIJIMA), one of the founders of the Doshisha, and Masanao NAKAMURA, a liberalist professor of the University of Tokyo, he was known as one of the three pillars of the Christian world.

sen.j: 娘に、後に津田塾大学創設者となる津田梅子がいる。
sen.e: His daughter Umeko TSUDA is a founder of Tsuda College.
His daughter Umeko TSUDA was a founder of Tsuda College.
His daughter Umeko TSUDA was a founder of Tsuda College.

sen.j: 幼名は千弥。
sen.e: His childhood name is Senya.
His childhood name was Senya.
His childhood name was Senya.

sen.j: 佐倉城内に生まれる。
sen.e: He was born in the Sakura-jo Castle.
He was born in the Sakura-jo Castle.
He was born in the Sakura-jo Castle.

sen.j: 父は下総国佐倉藩、堀田氏の家臣小島良親（善右衛門）の子で4男。
sen.e: His father is the fourth son of Yoshichika (Zenemon) KOJIMA, a vassal of Hotta clan in Sakura Domain of the Shimousa Province.
His father was the fourth son of Yoshichika (Zenemon) KOJIMA, a vassal of the Hotta clan in Sakura Domain of Shimousa Province.
sen.cmt: 過去形に直しました。Hotta clan→the Hotta clan
sen.e: His father was the fourth son of Yoshichika (Zenemon) KOJIMA, a vassal of the Hotta clan in Sakura Domain of Shimousa Province.

sen.j: 1851年、元服して桜井家の養子となる。
sen.e: In 1851, he reached the manhood and was adopted by the Sakurai family.
In 1851, he reached manhood and was adopted by the Sakurai family.
In 1851, he reached manhood and was adopted by the Sakurai family.

sen.j: 妻は初子で1861年に津田家の婿養子となる。
sen.e: His wife is Hatsuko and he was adopted by her family.
In 1861, he was adopted by his wife Hatsuko's family.
sen.cmt: 自然な表現になるよう修正しました。
sen.e: In 1861, he was adopted by his wife Hatsuko's family.

sen.j: 寛永4年、15歳で佐倉藩・藩校、成徳書院（現在の千葉県立佐倉高等学校の前身）で学ぶ。
sen.e: In 1627, at the age of 15, he studied at Seitoku Shoin, a hanko (domain school) of Sakura Domain (the predecessor of the present Chiba Prefectural Sakura Senior High School), and learned Dutch, English, Western studies and gunnery at command of domain, which was influenced by the lord of the domain Masayoshi HOTTA's inclination for Western studies.
sen.cmt: 津田氏が生まれたのは１８３７年で、ここの寛永４年（１６２７年）は間違いだと思われますが、原文どおりに訳しています。
sen.e: In 1627, at the age of 15, he studied at Seitoku Shoin, a hanko (domain school) in Sakura Domain (the predecessor of the present Chiba Prefectural Sakura Senior High School).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外処理
sen.e: In 1627, at the age of 15, he studied at Seitoku Shoin, a hanko (domain school) in Sakura Domain (the predecessor of the present Chiba Prefectural Sakura Senior High School).

sen.j: 藩主堀田正睦の洋学気風もあり、藩命でオランダ語、英語の他、洋学や砲術を学ぶ。
sen.e: The lord of the domain, Masayoshi HOTTA had a keen interest in Western studies, and under the domain's command, Sen studied Dutch, English, Western studies, and Gunnery.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外処理
sen.e: The lord of the domain, Masayoshi HOTTA had a keen interest in Western studies, and under the domain's command, Sen studied Dutch, English, Western studies, and Gunnery.

sen.j: 1855年に出仕し、江戸では蘭学塾へ入門し、森山栄之助の下で英語などを学ぶ。
sen.e: In 1855, he served the government and entered Rangaku Juku (Institute for Dutch Studies) in Edo to study English under Einosuke MORIYAMA.
In 1855, he entered government service, and enrolled in Rangaku Juku (Institute for Dutch Studies) in Edo to study English among other subjects under Einosuke MORIYAMA.
sen.cmt: among other subjectsを追記しました。
sen.e: In 1855, he entered government service, and enrolled in Rangaku Juku (Institute for Dutch Studies) in Edo to study English among other subjects under Einosuke MORIYAMA.

sen.j: 外国奉行の通訳として採用され、1867年（慶応3年）には福澤諭吉らと幕府随員としてアメリカ合衆国へ洋行。
sen.e: He was employed as a translator for a magistrate of foreign affairs and went to the United States of America in 1867 with Yukichi FUKUZAWA as an attendant for the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

He was employed as a translator for the magistrate of foreign affairs and went to the United States of America in 1867 with Yukichi FUKUZAWA as an attendant for the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).
sen.cmt: magistrateの前に冠詞を入れました。
sen.e: He was employed as a translator for the magistrate of foreign affairs and went to the United States of America in 1867 with Yukichi FUKUZAWA as an attendant for the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

sen.j: 明治維新が成ると官職を辞して、1869年には築地の洋風旅館、築地ホテルに勤め、西洋野菜の栽培などを手がける。
sen.e: Having left the government post after the Meiji Restoration, he worked for Tsukiji Hotel, a Western-style Japanese hotel, and cultivated Western vegetables.
Having left the government post after the Meiji Restoration, he worked for Tsukiji Hotel, a Western-style Japanese hotel, and cultivated Western vegetables.
Having left the government post after the Meiji Restoration, he worked for Tsukiji Hotel, a Western-style Japanese hotel, and cultivated Western vegetables.

sen.j: 1871年には明治政府が設立した開拓使の嘱託となる。
sen.e: In 1871, he worked as a temporary employee for Hokkaido Development Commission established by the Meiji Government and volunteered his daughter Umeko for its Iwakura Mission when Kiyotaka KURODA, Suke (assistant director) for the commission, who was interested in education for girls, planned to send female students with the mission.
sen.cmt: 団体としての「開拓使」はcommissionerではなくcommissionとなっていましたのでそちらを使用しました。http://www.mlit.go.jp/hkb/develop_e.html
sen.e: In 1871, he worked as a temporary employee for Hokkaido Development Commission established by the Meiji Government.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In 1871, he worked as a temporary employee for Hokkaido Development Commission established by the Meiji Government.

sen.j: 女子教育に関心のあった開拓次官の黒田清隆が、政府が派遣する岩倉使節団に女子留学生を随行させることを企画すると、娘の梅子を応募する。
sen.e: Kiyotaka KURODA, the Suke (assistant director), who was interested in education for girls, proposed to send female exchange students with the Iwakura mission, for which Sen volunteered his daughter, Umeko.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Kiyotaka KURODA, the Suke (assistant director), who was interested in education for girls, proposed to send female exchange students with the Iwakura mission, for which Sen volunteered his daughter, Umeko.

sen.j: 使節団が出発した翌月には開拓使を辞職。
sen.e: In the following month after the mission had departed, he resigned Hokkaido Development Commission.
One month after the delegation had departed, he resigned from the Hokkaido development commission.
One month after the delegation had departed, he resigned from the Hokkaido development commission.

sen.j: 民部省に勤めたのち、明治6（1873）年には、ウイーン万国博覧会に副総裁として出席する佐野常民（日本赤十字社の創設者）の書記官として随行。
sen.e: After working for Minbusho (Ministry of Popular Affairs), he accompanied Tsunetami SANO (the founder of the Japanese Red Cross Society) as a secretary when Sano attended the world exposition in Vienna as a vice-president.

After working for Minbusho (Ministry of Popular Affairs), he accompanied Tsunetami SANO (the founder of the Japanese Red Cross Society) as a secretary when Sano attended the world exposition in Vienna as a vice-president.

After working for Minbusho (Ministry of Popular Affairs), he accompanied Tsunetami SANO (the founder of the Japanese Red Cross Society) as a secretary when Sano attended the world exposition in Vienna as a vice-president.

sen.j: オランダ人農学者のダニエル・ホイブレイクの指導を受け、帰国後の74年5月に口述記録をまとめて『農業三事』として出版した。
sen.e: He was taught by a Dutch agriculturist Daniel HOOIBRENK and published "Nogyo Sanji" (three farming methods), a compilation of his dictation, in May, 1874 following his return to Japan.

He was taught by a Dutch agriculturist Daniel HOOIBRENK, and on May of 1874, following his return to Japan, he published a compilation of HOOIBRENK's dictations in "Nogyo Sanji" (three farming methods).

He was taught by a Dutch agriculturist Daniel HOOIBRENK, and on May of 1874, following his return to Japan, he published a compilation of HOOIBRENK's dictations in "Nogyo Sanji" (three farming methods).

sen.j: 明治8（1875）年1月、米国メソジスト監督派教会のジュリアス・ソーバー宣教師により日本初のメソジスト派第一号信者として妻の初と共に洗礼。
sen.e: In January, 1875, he was baptized with his wife Hatsu by Julius Soper, an American Methodist Episcopal missionary, as the first Japanese Methodist.
In January, 1875, he was baptized with his wife Hatsu by Julius Soper, an American Methodist Episcopal missionary, as the first Japanese Methodist.
In January, 1875, he was baptized with his wife Hatsu by Julius Soper, an American Methodist Episcopal missionary, as the first Japanese Methodist.

sen.j: 76年には東京麻布に学農社を設立、農学校も併設した。
sen.e: In 1876, he founded Gakunosha (an institution for publishing agricultural magazines and managing schools) along with an agricultural school in Azabu, Tokyo.
In 1876, he founded Gakunosha (an institution for publishing agricultural magazines and managing schools) as well an agricultural school in Azabu, Tokyo.
In 1876, he founded Gakunosha (an institution for publishing agricultural magazines and managing schools) as well an agricultural school in Azabu, Tokyo.

sen.j: キリスト教指導も行う。
sen.e: He taught Christianity as well.
He taught Christianity as well.
He taught Christianity as well.

sen.j: 仙が自ら創刊した「農業雑誌」で、1876年（明治9年）にアメリカ産トウモロコシの種の通信販売を始め、これが日本で最初の通信販売といわれている。
sen.e: In his magazine 'Nogyo Zasshi' (a magazine of agriculture), he started a mail order service for American corn seeds in 1876, which is said to be the first mail order service in Japan.
sen.cmt: 農学雑誌→「農業雑誌」が正しい名称だと思われますので変更致しました。
sen.e: In his magazine 'Nogyo Zasshi' (a magazine of agriculture), he sold American corn seeds by mail order; this was said to be the first mail order service in Japan.
sen.cmt: 自然な表現になるよう修正しました。
sen.e: In his magazine 'Nogyo Zasshi' (a magazine of agriculture), he sold American corn seeds by mail order; this was said to be the first mail order service in Japan.

sen.j: 同年には、栗原信近に招かれワイン醸造技術指導のため甲府を訪れている。
sen.e: In the same year, he was invited by Nobuchika KURIHARA to teach wine brewing technique in Kofu.
In the same year, he was invited by Nobuchika KURIHARA to teach wine making in Kofu.
In the same year, he was invited by Nobuchika KURIHARA to teach wine making in Kofu.

sen.j: 足尾鉱毒事件では田中正造を助け、農民救済運動に奔走。
sen.e: In the Ashio Copper Mine Mineral Pollution Incident, he supported Shozo TANAKA and devoted effort to relief work for the peasants.
In the Ashio Copper Mine Mineral Pollution Incident, he supported Shozo TANAKA and devoted effort to relief work for the peasants.
In the Ashio Copper Mine Mineral Pollution Incident, he supported Shozo TANAKA and devoted effort to relief work for the peasants.

sen.j: 1897年には事業を次男に譲り引退、鎌倉で過ごす。
sen.e: In 1897, he turned over his enterprises to his second son when he retired, and he lived in Kamakura.
In 1897, he turned over his enterprises to his second son, and retired in Kamakura.
sen.cmt: 自然な表現になるよう修正しました。
sen.e: In 1897, he turned over his enterprises to his second son, and retired in Kamakura.

sen.j: 1908年、東海道本線の車内で脳出血のため71歳で死去。
sen.e: In 1908, he died of a brain hemorrhage on the Tokaido Main Line train at the age of 71.
In 1908, he died of a brain hemorrhage on the Tokaido Main Line train at the age of 71.
In 1908, he died of a brain hemorrhage on the Tokaido Main Line train at the age of 71.

sen.j: 葬儀は青山学院の講堂で行われた。
sen.e: His funeral was held at the auditorium of Aoyama Gakuin.
His funeral was held at the auditorium of Aoyama Gakuin.
His funeral was held at the auditorium of Aoyama Gakuin.

sen.j: 死後、内村鑑三や新渡戸稲造らは仙の事業を讃える一文を残し、「大平民」と称された。
sen.e: After his death, Kanzo UCHIMURA and Inazo NITOBE dedicated a memorial writing to Sen for praising his work, and he was called 'Daiheimin' (the great commoner).
sen.cmt: 「一文」を「追悼文」と訳したほうが理解しやすいため、そのように訳しました。
sen.e: After his death, Kanzo UCHIMURA and Inazo NITOBE wrote a eulogy, praising his life works called him 'Daiheimin' (the great commoner).
After his death, Kanzo UCHIMURA and Inazo NITOBE wrote a eulogy, praising his life works called him 'Daiheimin' (the great commoner).

sen.j: 仙がウィーン万博から持ち帰ったニセアカシアの種子は、帰国後の明治8年に大手町に植えられ、これが東京初の街路樹となった。
sen.e: The seeds of false acacia that Sen had brought back from the world exposition in Vienna were planted in Otemachi in 1875 following his return to Japan, which became the first roadside trees in Tokyo.
The seeds of pseudoacacia that Sen had brought back from the world exposition in Vienna were planted in Otemachi in 1875 following his return to Japan, which became the first roadside trees in Tokyo.
The seeds of pseudoacacia that Sen had brought back from the world exposition in Vienna were planted in Otemachi in 1875 following his return to Japan, which became the first roadside trees in Tokyo.

sen.j: 墓所は青山霊園。
sen.e: His grave is in Aoyama Cemetery.
His grave is in Aoyama Cemetery.
His grave is in Aoyama Cemetery.
